title: 106_s1468
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States Capitol Visitor Center Commemorative Coin Act of 1999". Congress finds that the Capitol building in Washington, D.C. is a significant symbol of democracy, attracting millions of visitors annually. The building lacks necessary facilities for visitors, but has excellent security provided by the United States Capitol Police. Congress has allocated $100,000,000 for improvements. Congress has appropriated $100,000,000 to construct a Capitol Visitor Center to enhance security and the visitor experience at the Capitol. Congress has allocated $100,000,000 for the construction of a Capitol Visitor Center to improve security and visitor experience. Private funds will also be used for the project. Additionally, Congress is encouraging voluntary participation in fundraising for the center and authorizing the minting of coins to support the construction efforts. The Congress has allocated funds for the construction of a Capitol Visitor Center to enhance security and visitor experience. Proceeds from the sale of commemorative coins will support the construction, maintenance, and preservation of the center. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue bimetallic $10 coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $1 silver coins weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. Additionally, half dollar clad coins will be minted weighing 11.34 grams, with a diameter of 1.205 inches, following specifications in section 5112(b) of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary may mint $5 gold coins if bimetallic coins are not feasible, with specifications including a weight of 8.359 grams, a diameter of 0.850 inches, and a composition of 90% gold and 10% alloy. The Secretary has the option to mint $5 gold coins if bimetallic coins are not feasible, with specific details on weight, diameter, and composition. These coins will be legal tender. SEC. 4. The Secretary will obtain platinum, gold, and silver from available sources for minting coins. SEC. 5. The design of coins will be determined. The design of coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the first meeting of the United States Congress in the United States Capitol Building, with inscriptions including the coin's value, the year "2000", and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum".
